text:
I have been making this for a solid 5 years and has been a hit everytime!  But I always add something green, usually chopped green onions and place 4-5 stalk on top befor baking to make it visually appealing.  You can also add chopped can chiles or diced pimentos (in a jar) for great color.  And using low fat sour cream tastes exactly the same too.  But after 5 years, and using 3 different ovens, this dish always takes about 50-55 min. to bake, not 45 min.  Can also make ahead and refridgerate before you need to bake, just let it sit at room temperature for at least 30-45 min.  Great for making ahead for a dinner party. Be sure to print out recipes because you will get asked!

text:
This really is very easy.  I wanted to "test drive" this dish before Thanksgiving and I have now made it twice for my husband.  It's made the cut!  We think that it reminds us of hushpuppies so we call it "Hushpuppy Casserole." The first time I made this I added the extra water from the canned corn, as suggested.  That made it overly moist.  This time I poured in only half of the corn water and we both thought the dish was better (it was a little firmer).  I agree that real butter is the best (but the first time I used margarine, and it tasted fine!) My mother-in-law suggested adding bacon, too. I find, depending on the dish, it might take longer to bake than you were planning on. Still, nothing beats this dish--YUM!

text:
I've made this casserole for Thanksgiving the last two years.  There is never a crumb left!  Everyone loves it.  I make it with only 3 TBSP melted butter and 1 egg, plus 1/2 cup chopped onion.  This makes it lighter and more savory. I bake it at 350 for 1 hour.  Another plus to this recipe is when I make it for Thanksgiving I double it and put it in my 9x13 Pyrex portable glass pan with a microwaveable warmer.  I make it earlier, then bring a great side dish that doesn't require valuable oven space!

country:
None
text:
I have found the best way to cook this recipe is to take 1 stick of butter and put it in a 9x12 glass pyrex baking dish.  Put it in the oven at 350 until it melts.  Swish it around until the butter covers the entire bottom of the dish.  Mix together the other ingredients (omitting the 1/2 cup of butter) and just pour over the top of the butter without mixing. This is the same concept as the cobbler recipe I have seen and used.  Then, just bake it uncovered until it puffs up and is nicely browned on the top. The butter gives it a crispy texture and is delicious.  I have doubled this recipe also.  Last time, I even added one egg and it didn't seem to really make that much difference. IT will be all gone I can guarantee it!! I think I baked mine almost an hour the last time. If yo double it, it may take a little longer.  Good Luck!

text:
This is definitely on the top of the list of requests for dinner sides.  I have made it full fat and reduced fat and still have the same great response! I use a 1/2 cup of egg beaters, reduced fat sour cream and margarine (instead of butter). Bake at 375 for an hour and 15 minutes; it turns out beautifully. LOVE THIS ONE!!

text:
My turn! I doubled the recipe for a 9x13 glass pan, which I sprayed with Pam instead of using melted butter. This was my batter: 4 eggs, beaten; two cans Mexican-style canned corn, to get the red and green pepper bits; 2 cans creamed corn; 2 packages dry corn bread mix; 2 cups of light sour cream; 1 teaspoon sugar; 1/3 cup of sharp Cheddar cheese; 1/4  teaspoon vanilla and -- because it's the holidays -- 1/4 cup light-style eggnog. Made it nice and moist.  I baked for 75 minutes and topped with more of the cheese at the 70-minute mark.  The potluck crowd loved it!

text:
Yummy!  This was my favorite side dish as a child.  Nothing beats a corn casserole made with fresh corn- the milk from the cut kernels provides an amazing flavor that just can't be duplicated. But this recipe is quite tasty, and it is easy enough that a youngster could be assigned to make it.  If you follow this recipe, you get a dense casserole that can almost be served like a cornbread.  Because I prefer the lightness of a corn souffle, I really cut back on the cornbread mix and used maybe 3/4 of a 6.5 oz package of Betty Crocker corn muffin mix.  I also used frozen corn instead of canned because their texture is more like that of fresh corn, and I probably used 1/4 cup more corn than the recipe called for.

text:
WOW!! This recipe amazed me! Economical,quick, and yummy! Followed the recipe except for a handful of sharp cheddar I threw in with the batter. For the record, I was really disappointed with the dish when I first tasted it. It had just come out of the oven and was still pretty soupy. After it got to room temp it had set much better. From now on, I will make this early in the day so it will be ready for dinner. Room temp was the ticket for me!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe for many types of dinners or parties.  I always add "something green".  Either minced green pepper, minced jalapeno, cilantro or chives.  It adds some color and flavor. Some other additions through the years have been Bacon (pepper bacon is best), some shreaded cheddar cheese, or a little bit of extra corn bread mixture on the top for crunch.  In the summer time, I've used fresh corn to mix in and I always use the low fat sour cream - lastly, I've never found this to cook in less than 50-60 minutes.  Give it some extra time to get a slight crust on top and check it in the middle to be sure it is cooked through and set - otherwise it is not very good.  It is also great for leftovers!

Wow, this is good stuff! The title says it all... awesome and easy.
I started out with Marie Callendar's Original Cornbread Mix, which, IMHO... is the best out there. I found out I was out of whole corn, so I just went ahead and used 2 cans of creamed, cutting the sour cream by half. Added 1/2 can diced green chiles and baked for 1 hour. Perfect.
Ruthie, thank you so much for this delicious, comfort food recipe... my hubby starts drooling each time I tell him it's on the menu! LOL

text:
I rate very few recipes especially if I alter them in any way because it is not fair to the submitter. BUT - this recipe is a KEEPER! I have had this once before in my life at a pot luck and I loved it but never tried to make it. Then I was asked to bring a corn side dish to a family get together, I didn't want to do a throw frozen corn in the microwave kind of thing so came here to see what I could see. This one caught my eye, decided to try it. WOW! Simple ingredients, so easy to put together - one bowl - one spoon - one pan. Followed the recipe exactly as written, doubled as the submitter suggested. Made and baked the night before then slipped into the oven when I arrived at my Dad's house just to warm it through. Came out perfectly moist and delicious. Everyone wanted the recipe and even my picky husband (who prefers the old frozen corn in the microwave :)) LOVED it. Thank you LETSGGGO - this is going to be one of my "go to" sides from now on.

text:
Well I just did a test run of this recipe this evening as I plan on taking it to a family Easter gathering Sunday.  Followed the ingredients listed, but felt it needed something else.  So I decided to add a can of diced green chilies and some cheese to the batter.  Smells awesome!!  Letting it cool down a bit before serving.  ***Update with Star Rating*** The tasting results are in - it was "ehhhh"...nothing to write home about.  Very heavy.  Definitely needed A LOT of spice (more than what I added when I deviated from the recipe a tad) as opposed to none as the recipe is written.  As my fiance said...it was a one note dish, very monotonous (corn corn corn corn and a little hint of cheese).  I can only imagine what would have been like without the cheese and green chili addition.  Probably wont make this again, unless I'm in a corn pudding kinda mood.

text:
I decided to try this recipe for Thanksgiving. I have made it three times already! The first time I made it according to the original recipe. I thought it was a bit to bland and chunky. So, I decided to change it according to some of the suggestions given. I added 1/4 cup butter (instead of half a cup), 1/2 cup sugar and ommitted the one can of whole kernel corn. It was absolutely FANTASTIC! Almost like the "corn tamalito" from Chevy's or El Torito restaurant! The other version I made was to use 1/2 cup of yogurt instead of the one cup of sour cream and parmesan cheese on top. This was also delicious but more moist. I can't wait to make it again!

text:
Great recipe!  We love Corn just not canned corn.  
CHANGES: used frozen corn---steam bag then put it in an empty can for measuring.   Used 2/3 of frozen tube southern style white sweet cream corn.  Smothered 1/2 sweet vidallia onion and 1/3 red bell pepper in the butter ...added to mixture once cooled.   Used Jiffy cornbread mix.   Mixed the night before then refrigerated till morning.  Baked the net day (am).

text:
I had to laugh when I read the negative reviews.  One person said it had "too much corn in it"????  I love this recipe.  My grandma used to make a baked corn recipe, but she used breadcrumbs.  This is so much easier and equally tasty.  After baking it the posted amount of time, it wasn't golden on top but clearly set in the middle.  I turned on the broiler for just a minute and got a wonderful golden brown color on top.  The recipe doesn't call for salt, but it seemed like it could have used some.  It still is a wonderful dish to serve, especially if you're a busy mom like me and want to serve something besides plain old steamed veggies all the time.

Creamy comfort food. This would be great on a cold winter's night. As it was, it was pretty tasty in 100 degree weather. My kids and finicky husband loved it, but I think I loved it the most.
At seven months pregnant, it's nice to eat something that makes me feel happy and comfortable. One word of caution, it take slonger than 45 minutes to cook. This is a definite keeper and a good pick me up.

This was a welcomed addition to my Thanksgiving table. I doubled the recipe so I could use my 9x13 baking dish since I didn't have a 9x9. text:
With a few changes you can make this look like a souffle that took hours to make!
Subsitute:   
1 - 8 1/2 oz pkg Jiffy Muffin Mix in place of the breadcrumbs
1 stick of melted butter in place of 2 eggs

Bake in souffle dish (aprrox 9" round) for 1 hour or until golden brown.

It's as beautiful as delicious.  Enjoy!

text:
This is what we call Spoon Bread and I've been making this same recipe for over 10 years.  It's always a hit and an easy side dish.  This recipe calls for a 9x9 pan but I've always used a 9x13 pan.  And if you use stoneware or glass you can melt the butter right in the baking dish in the microwave and then add the ingredients and mix and bake them right in the same pan.  Easy enough for the novice and tasty enough to serve company.

I have been making this for Thanksgiving for at least 10 years now. My family would be disappointed if I didn't. I do mix it up the day/night before and put it in my 20 x 15 turkey baking pan (as I always double the recipe.) However, I couldn't get it to cook evenly in a 9 x 13 pan... It was runny in the middle. I also have to cook it much longer than the recipe calls for... I start checking after 45 minutes, but I usually find it takes about 60 minutes or more. Thanks for a great recipe!I also added salt.

text:
I read through the reviews and came up with this.   Melt butter in dish around 9 inches.   Mix remaining ingredients, except butter and add 4 tablespoons of sugar and pour over top of melted butter.   Bake at 375 for 1 hour.   Comes out with a crunchy bottom and stays together.   Yum all the way.

userID:

Display Name:
RobinStyler

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/729952.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have Jiffy so I used the following ingredients to substitute for the Jiffy:

2/3 cup all-purpose flour
1/2 cup yellow cornmeal
3 tablespoons granulated sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
2 tablespoons vegetable oil

After making this a couple of times at full fat, I decided to play around and was able to substitute Fat Free Greek Gods Yogurt for the Sour Cream.  The only trick to that is to add a Tablespoon of Vinegar to the milk and let it sit  for five minutes.  Without doing that, it makes the casserole bland.  Trust me, it's good!

I also replaced half of the butter once with coconut oil and once with butter flavored shortening.  Both are fine substitutions. 

I use a 50/50 mix of white and wheat flour and usually bake with powdered eggs (don't cringe) and this recipe gets eaten no matter how much I play around with it.  

I have to agree with (and thank) the other reviewers that this needs around an hour in the over.  I set my timer at 55 minutes and just keep an eye on it.  For those who are oven checkers, the casserole doesn't drop no matter how many times you check in on it!  Enjoy~

text:
I make this all the time for pot lucks and holidays and it's always a huge hit. The eggs aren't necessary, I never add them and it still turns out perfect. For those who like it on the sweeter side, instead of adding sugar I highly recommend adding honey (as I always do to my cornbread also), it's much better than using refined sugar and gives it almost a glaze on top. I also agree that this takes closer to an hour to cook, not 45 minutes. For a savory version of this I would recommend adding shredded cheddar, green onions and jalapenos if you like a little kick!

text:
This was very good!  I would recommend cutting the butter next time, maybe even in half.  Here's how I did mine: I used 1 can creamed corn and then used that can to measure my frozen reg. corn. I added about 1/2 cup chopped sweet onion.  I did as a previous reviewer suggested, I melted butter in the pan directly in the oven then added the filling without mixing it.  That way a crust develops.  That may be part of the reason I had standing butter on top but I will still try cutting it next time b/c it was still good after I had to soak up all that standing butter with paper towels. Will definitely make this again!

text:
Saw this recipe and it just sounded too good to pass up. I had all the ingredients on hand except creamed corn. Decided I couldn't let that whip me so I used 2 cans of whole kernel corn and mixed it with an 8 oz. pkg. of softened cream cheese. Tossed in a can of green chilies, a dash of cayenne, and the rest was history. Truly a great recipe. I baked it in a 2 quart baking dish because a 9 x 9 inch dish wouldnt hold it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1760.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to admit I was surprised at how absolutely DELICIOUS this is! Thought it would be too cake-y, but no---turned out to be a perfect side dish. I make the double recipe in a 9"x13" pan, with the addition of about 1 Tbl sugar. (Why bother with the smaller size when everyone LOVES IT???) Another plus: I make it in a glass baking dish the day before I'm serving it. Flavors meld overnight and it reheats perfectly in the microwave. Leftovers (on the rare day there are any!) also re-heat great in the microwave. It's terrific with baked ham, pork chops, turkey, chicken, roast beef.....actually, it outshines the main dish! Kids & adults love it....There is absolutely NOTHING negative to say about this dish....well, OK, a little calorie rich, but when something is sooooo good, who cares? It's one of those rare dishes that is worth the calorie splurge!  Just take that fork and enjoy!

text:
I have made so many corn casserole/baked corn recipes over the years trying to find just the right combination that everyone loves. this is by far, the best all-around one that I've found. I have made it exactly like the recipe calls (although I do use a 9x13 pan and cook until golden brown, which is sometimes a bit longer than the 45 minutes. I have also made it with 1/2 the corn bread mix for a variation (depends on who I'm serving) and it comes out more like a souffle. Both are excellent and I pass this recipe around every Thanksgiving and Christmas when my friends call asking for "that corn bake recipe".

text:
To make this more of a moist cornbread, use small cans (8.75oz) of creamed corn and corn kernels and reduce the sour cream to 1/3 cup.  Reduced the butter to 6 tablespoons.  I also add 1 cup of shredded cheddar cheese.  Cook for 45 min at 350 and you've got a moist cornbread.  Very yummy!

text:
The "four stars" is just a personal reaction to what I perceive to be a rather bland taste to this recipe "as is", but it's still a wonderful (and after the recent dinner at which I served it, popular) dish.  I added some jalapeno peppers (finally chopped, about 3 tbsp) and topped it with cheddar cheese.  That added a nice little "kick" and some additional flavor that folks seemed to enjoy (everyone wanted the recipe!).  I also used "Mexicali corn" for some color.  By the way, I noted that some reviewers had some problems with baking consistency... I didn't find that to be a problem as it turned out nicely golden albeit with a slightly longer cooking time.  Thanks, Ruthie, for a quick and easy recipe.  Both your original and my "doctored" version will remain on the menu here for friends to enjoy!

userID:
8326279
Display Name:
Deepika Neel
isPro:

followersCount:

2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1759178.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe and SUPER easy to make! I made it for the very first time for thanksgiving and I was kinda apprehensive about how it would turn out, but it was a definite hit with everyone!! I doubled the recipe and it fit perfectly in a 9x13 pan. I used someone's advice here, and put half a cup of butter in the dish to melt in the oven and mixed the other half with the rest of the ingredients. I used Marie calendar's original corn bread mix and cans of both the whole kernel corn and creamed corn. I also used a tablespoon of sugar and a splash of vanilla. I baked it for little over an hour, probably closer to 75 minutes until it was beautifully brown at the top. It came out a little swishy and it got me a little worried but it cooled down and solidified a lot more. After an hour or so, it had the perfect pudding consistency. Like I said, everyone loved it and it was the first dish to get eaten fully! :) I'll definitely make this one again! I would try and cut down the butter by half and the sugar to one tablespoon, but it's fantastic just as! Thanks for this great recipe, it really helps amateur cooks like me look better :)

LOVE IT!!!!  I have been making this recipe for over 30 years. It was passed down from my mother in law to me. I usually make this the night before Thanksgiving and reheat the next day. I think it tastes better this way. The sour cream really works it's magic on the corn by dinner time. I try to cook at least one 13 X 9 pan in a glass dish, so I can heat it in the microwave if needed. This is so popular at our family gatherings that I now make 3 large pans, so family members can take some home!!

Well, I am a big corn lover anyway, but since we had an abundance of corn from the garden this summer, I roasted 4 ears of corn in the oven, then cut the kernels off of those, and measured out the corn and I would need for the recipe. I did everything else the same, salt and pepper to taste, of course, but added finely chopped scallions sprinkled over the top halfway through baking time. I almost wanted to eat half of it by myself, but restrained, and shared with the family.Haha. They loved it! Thank you for a great recipe

text:
I have made this recipe many times for office potlucks and holiday get-togethers. It's great to make ahead the night before, and warms up beautifully in the microwave or oven. I sometimes add diced ham and cheddar cheese for an "all-in-one" main dish casserole. The kids love it. I've found when I add ham and cheese that it takes longer to bake - more like an hour total. I've easily doubled and even tripled this recipe with great success. Just add 10 - 15 mins onto the baking time. Once you make this, you will asked for the recipe, so be prepared!

text:
OMG this was so good!!!! I reduced the butter by a tablespoon and added a  cup or so of finely shredded cheddar and a small can of green chilies that I drained slightly. Beautiful golden "crust" and soft, moist interior. However, mine was in the oven for a hour with the heat on to cook. At 45 minutes a skewer still looked too damp. Probably because I added stuff. :P Residual heat let this sit in the oven to hold for dinner while I cooked other things and it reheats in the microwave beautifully. I will absolutely be making this again since this was a test run on new recipes for Thanksgiving. YUM!

I made this yesterday and my husband loved it!  I followed a few suggestions from other reviewers and used frozen corn (thawed) to equal 15 ounces, added a handful of shredded cheddar cheese, used regular onion and some chopped green pepper (sauted til soft), some chili powder for spice and a shake of salt. This dish is my favorite thing to make for holiday dinners & party potlucks! It's so easy to make, looks like it took a lot of work, & is delicious. I made it my 1st time, & everybody loved it. 

I followed the recipe, and double everything. Except I used less butter- 1/2 cup, and only 2 eggs. I used Martha's All natural cornbread mix instead of the Jiffy mix. Jiffy has LARD in it! I also  added some chopped green onions & mild cheddar cheese. Perfect dish. Baked it for 1 hour. Prepared it in 5 minutes.

text:
I have made this for 20 years. I simplified it somewhere along the way. 1 stick butter melted, use the wrapper to grease the pan, 1 can each of ( high quality) cream and kernel corn, 1 egg, 1 box corn muffin mix, 1 container sour cream, mix it all up and bake for about an hour.  Always requested and always delicious.

text:
Delicious!  I made this for the first time as a side to our ham for Christmas dinner.  I have to admit I was a little skeptical of all the sour cream, but I followed the recipe exactly, doubling it so we'd have enough for everyone, and it turned out beautifully.  It was moist, subtly sweet, and I could just barely detect the slight tang from the sour cream . . . perfect!  Exactly the recipe I was looking for!  Like a cross between a sweet corn bread and the Mexican corn cake you can get at Mexican restaurants.  Our guests raved about this dish.  I think it was everyone's favorite, and wound up having very little left over.  I will definitely be making this again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic! As others have done, I added 2 teaspoons of brown sugar,  salt and pepper. That seemed to give it a little more flavor.  It is a little hard to tell when it is done. Don't bother to stick a toothpick in it like you would a cake. It firms up a little after removing from the oven.  I took mine out of the oven, and shook it to see how much it jiggled. The less it moves, the more it is done. Also watch for some slight cracking on the surface. The browning on top isn't a very good way to tell if it is done or not.

text:
I made this for two separate Thanksgiving lunch and dinner events I was attending.  For the first batch, I followed the recipe as written, but added 2 tablespoons of sugar and baked for 60 minutes.  It turned out perfect!  For the second batch, I added half a can of the water from the corn and the same amount of sugar as the first time.  It turned out good, but the consistency was definitely better without the addition of the water.  Either way, this recipe is a winner and I will be making it in the future!

I've made this several times and it always gets rave reviews.  I use Jiffy Corn Muffin Mix because it's a bit sweeter than traditional corn bread mixes. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I tried this I wasn't all that thrilled, but I decided to give it a second chance and I am really enjoying this now.  I omitted the can of corn (kept the can of creamed corn), I added 1 and a half tblspns of sugar and two dashes of nutmeg, and I used half sour cream and half cream cheese.  The end result is a slightly sweet, savory, and creamy corn pudding suffle!  If you're not expecting the texture then I can understand some of the negative reviews (which was my issue the first time I made it) but if you know what to expect you can adjust the flavor to your liking.  I also used a square pyrex dish, baked it only for 45 minutes, turned off the oven, cracked it open, and let it sit in there for another 5 minutes or so.  It's perfect.

userID:
2163819
Display Name:
taylor49

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this Xmas eve after reading all of the reviews, noting variations. Used all ingredients in recipe, except only used 11oz can of corn rather than 15. I incorporated the following suggestions by previous reviewers. One sauteed small onion and Roma tomato.  I did add 2 tbs of sugar; next time I would add one as I prefer it more savory than sweet. Used 1/2 cup sour cream and 1/2 cup cream cheese.  This worked to a very nice taste.  Sprinkled in some chili powder/cumin.  Should have added a little more; maybe a tbs. Also added a 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp white pepper.  The best suggestion was adding some shredded cheese blend on top and broiling a few minutes at the end.  This added a wonderful crunch. There were many opinions about the texture so I wasnt sure how it should turn out. I think the souffle description is best, dry and crunchy on the outside, very moist on the inside.  This is a good recipe with lots of opportunities to make it a "personal one". Would definately make it again..

text:
I scaled this to 57 servings, in order for it to come out in even number of cans.  It is a great favorite for our Salvation Army pitch in dinners.
I place it in two large industrial size type disposable baking pans.  Due to number of servings, it takes considerably longer to cook.  Best way to test is with toothpick, and look for golden top.   Everyone absolutely loves this gem.
Larry Emsweller
Munster, Indiana

text:
I have made this a couple of times now and thought I should write a review.  I think this is a wonderful recipe and goes very well with a steaming bowl full of chili!  My husband's Aunt gave me a collection of family recipes as a wedding gift and she has a delicious recipe for a similar casserole, yet it has mayonnaise, grated cheese, chopped onion, etc.  While it tastes fabulous, I found that this recipe tastes just as great and we don't even miss the extra ingredients (or calories).  Thanks for a delicious, super easy casserole!

Just made this for the 3rd time in 2 weeks. It is more awesome each time! This last time, I followed the recipe except for NOT draining the can of regular corn; added some chili pepper, and 1 cup of shredded "Pepper Jack" cheese (monterey jack cheese with jalapeno peppers). text:
I altered this by using a 6oz. packet of the Martha White Mexican style cornbread mix, 1/2 cup of butter, 1 egg, 1 can of creamed corn, 1 tbsp. diced jalapenos, 1/4 cup of jalepeno juice from the jar, and 1-1/2 cups of the monterey jack cheese with peppers.  This casserole came out perfect, it was not too pepper hot - totally awesome.  I would rather have this then corn bread anytime.

None
text:
I've been making this for about 10 yrs now...always to rave reviews & someone always asks me for the recipe!  Now, it's become my sister's favorite asked for side dish too!!  I found out, accidentally, that when I beat the ingredients (I thought!) too much w/a fork & left it sit on the counter for about 1/2 hr. ..& THEN put it in a 300• oven (I had just cooked chicken wings before that @ that temperature) & forgot to turn it to 350• , which is the temp I usually bake the corn casserole.  Well, the casserole actually cane out even better..  It was fluffier, moister & just delicious! Now...I ALWAYS cook it this way..I beat the ingredients, let it set on counter for 1/2 hr & bake for an hour @ 309•.

text:
Took this dish to a barbeque last night and got many compliments, plus my husband loved it. I doubled the recipe and made it in a 9" X 13" baking dish. I also substituted plain (not fat free) greek yogurt for the sour cream and added diced baby red and orange sweet peppers for some color interest. I also stirred it twice (20 minutes and 40 minutes into cooking) to speed up the center getting set.

text:
I didnt make this but it is so close to my mom's corn casserole recipe that we make every year.  It gets rave reviews & there's rarely any left. My son likes it cold!
The only difference in the recipe is we do not put butter in it, but we do add 1/3 cup sugar & 1/2 cup oil. Bake @350 for about 1 hour.
It is sweet, so a little less sugar wouldnt hurt it, altho most folks do like the sweetness.

text:
Love this! Been making it for 3 plus yrs. I use half the butter, and also some of the water from canned corn. I omit the sour cream for my own taste and it comes out great. Works good in pyrex but it's even better in cupcake liners so everyone has their own piece. I just place the batter in cupcake liners and cook until a toothpick comes out clean at 350 degrees. Lately I have been adding extra ingredients like half with chopped chives and half with shredded cheese to spruce it up. Each were delicious. Great and easy recipe to experiment with. This is the dish I am always asked to bring for the holidays.

Yummy!  This recipe is beautiful in it's simplicity and so versatile!  I brought this as a side dish to Easter dinner and it was a hit.  I made it the night before in a 9" stoneware, (as other reviewers suggested it needed just over an hour to bake) cooled to room temp, covered with foil and refridgerated overnight, then reheated in the oven the next day just before serving. text:
i've made this recipe several times and we LOVE it!  however, tonight, after a day of baking adventures, when i turned my attention to dinner preparations, i found myself out of butter AND down to about a tlbs of sour cream!  but i wanted corn casserole to go with my smoked brisket and baked beans, so i decided to do an experiment.  i made this recipe without butter, with a scant couple spoonfuls of sour cream, and the addition of some really sharp wisconsin cheddar.  amazing!  who knew you could cut out all that fat and calories and still have a tasty result??  this will be something we eat a bit more often now that i know cutting out some of the less healthy ingredients doesn't completely ruin it.  the mark of a great recipe, thanks!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use Cope's Corn instead of the creamed corn. For those of you not familiar with it, Cope's is a dried, cracked corn that is usually boiled or soaked before you use it. It was a perennial favorite in Ohio where I grew up. Cope's corn is already pre-sweetened, so I use plain corn meal instead of the cornbread mix. The flavor of Cope's is unique, and I think it really makes this recipe pop! Using Cope's makes the recipe a bit more work, but it's definitely worth it.

This was so good!  I read a lot of reviews and made just a few modifications.  I added about 1/2 tsp. sugar, 1/8 c. finely chopped green peppers and 1/8 c. chopped green onion.  I cooked it for about 35 minutes on 350.  I was also making baked fish, so I turned up the oven to 425 and let the casserole cook with the fish for another 10-15 minutes, making sure the top didn't get too brown.  Will definitely be making this again!  A huge hit!

text:
In one word:  Cornalicious!  I make this every Thanksgiving and Christmas.  This recipe is great and easy just as it is, but I use this as a base for many variations.  I always add one diced sauteed onion and decrease the butter to 1/4 cup (it can tend to be greasy) and always add about 1/2 pound of grated cheese(pepper jack or cheddar work very well).  You can then mix in some Rotel or just plain diced chilis.  Or diced red peppers work well too.  A couple of diced chipotles in adobo is out of this world.  Just let your imagination run wild!  XOXO

text:
I AM NOT A BAKING KIND OF GIRL , but this was super easy and made me look like a pro more than once. It baked up beautiful every time I have done it. Perfect color and flavor. This is not the thick custard type corn pudding but it is THEE PERFECT texture for me, just enough golden crust and creamy/eggy/fluffy insides. IT IS PERFECTION, follow the recipe exactly and DO NOT OVER MIX. I think if you wanted to add bacon or onions they would be great or any extra seasoning. Corny cornbread goodness in every bite =D  If you are looking for a corn pudding recipe you have found one of the best! DELICIOUS!

I will definetly cook this again - but I will experiment and try using frozen corn instead of canned next time.  But I will use the canned creamed corn. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The final taste of this dish very much depends on the quality of the ingredients.  Use corn with good flavor.  I used Libbys super sweet canned corn and everyone loved it.  If you use bland, generic corn you may end up with a bland dish.  I also added a couple of slices of extra sharp chedder cheese into the dish.  Add up to 1/3 cup of sugar if you want a sweeter mix.  This is easy to whip up in the food processor.  Just stir in the corns once the other stuff is mixed together. Cooking time for me was 60 minutes but I used a deeper casserole dish.

text:
Oh man was this good! After reading the reviews here, I knew it would turn out more like a corn bread than a casserole, so I split the batter between a muffin tray and an 8X8 pan. The muffins were done in 20 minutes and they were perfect! Slightly crisp on the outside and light and creamy on the inside; sheer heaven! (I didn’t share!) I served the remaining casserole portion as a side dish and it was well received. I ate the leftovers for breakfast. Clearly I’ll have to make this infrequently or my butt will get too big for my chair! Thanks for the great recipe!

This was a nice corn side dish that my husband and I both enjoyed. At the store I only found 7 oz. bags of cornbread mix, but that didn't seem to mess up this recipe at all. I also only had an 8' by 8' pan and this baked up perfect golden brown in that pan. The only downfall for me in this dish is it was a bit eggy. We like our corn casserole a little dryer in the middle, like Chi Chi's yummy side dish. This was a tasty recipe but I think I will keep looking for the perfect corn casserole for us.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe was delicious.  However, instead of using canned corn kernels, I used frozen sweet corn kernels (I'm not fond of "canned" veggies), blanched in boiling water.  I did use canned creamed corn though.  My pan was 8 x 8 x 2 deep, so I had to add 20 minutes to the baking time.  I added a pinch of cayenne pepper to the batter for a little kick.  My mother and father loved this dish!  Actually, my chocolate lab, Mackie, thoroughly enjoyed a few bites of this too.  The casserole turned out absolutely delicious.  Next time, I'm planning on serving it with chili con carne.  YUMMY stuff!

text:
Due to reviews & my experiences, I thought this would be bland without adding some things. I added 1/2 c. shredded Mexican cheese & think 3/4 c. might be better. Instead of 1 cup sour cream, I used 1/2 c. reduced fat sour cream + 1/2 cup Ranch Dip. Because I was out of fresh onions, I added some dried chopped onions.  I believe it would have been lacking without these addition. As suggested,  I reduced the butter to 5 tablespoons & believe that's enough. I also cooked it in a 9 x 13 pan & for longer than the 45 minutes.

Display Name:
tom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this for 4 years now for Thanksgiving.  It is a hit and here to stay.  as others have mentioned in the past, I essentially double the recipe, but use 1 cup of sour cream and and 1 stick softened (microwaved) cream cheese.  I use 3 boxes of corn muffin mix (instead of 2) as I like mine a little more cakey.  I also add 2 small cans of diced chilis, and a handful of shredded cheddar. I do not double the butter as I think 1 stick is plenty.  so summary:  4 eggs, 1 stick butter, 1 stick cream cheese, 1 cup sour cream, 3 boxes jiffy corn muffin mix, 2 small cans diced chilis.   I also grease a pyrex large casserole dish with the butter flavored shortening. it is option if you want to sprinkle cheese on top.  this time I did not, just mixed some in...because it is a pretty thick, deep mix in my dish, i baked at 325 for about 45 min, then finished at 350 to help brown.  probably another 20 min.  pyrex is great because you can see the bottom through the pyrex...

country:

text:
I got this recipe from a friend over 10 years ago and use to make it a lot in the beginning. Now on just special occasions since it makes a lot. I add about 1/4 cup of honey to cut the bitterness of the corn bread mix. Just a tip, if you are making this and not sure if it's done, the toothpick trick will not work since it's a partially wet dish and it doesn't brown a whole lot on the top. I just jiggle it after 40-45 minutes and it if doesn't move, it's done. I like the stir it up after about 5 minutes of taking out of the oven to incorporate the two textures together.

text:
Followed directions exactly. Too moist, did not stick together when scooped out of 9x9 pan. Also, I cooked it for 65 minutes at 350 and it was still not golden brown on top. Had to put it in for 10 minutes more on 375. Husband recommended less corn. Next time: I will just use the can of cream corn and cook it on 375 for 50 minutes, to see if that helps. The taste was great and it was a hybrid between a souffle and cornbread.

text:
Would have given it 10 stars if I could have! Perfect recipe as written! After reading some reviews I was nervous. Some people saying it was bland, or added green onions, bacon , chilies, etc. I made the recipe as written. Using a store brand can of corn (which was drained of the liquid), a name brand can of creamed corn, butter,sour cream, 2 jumbo eggs( which was all I had),and the "J"  blue & white box of cornbread mix. I added a couple of grinds of fresh black pepper(for the hubby, I hate pepper,so it wasn't a lot.)  Plus a tablespoon of sugar. My whole family raved about it!  I just made it ,without a warning word of "trying a new recipe"!  It was "ooohed", and "oh my goodness", what is this, "it's so good"! So good in fact, that this is the first recipe I ever rated! I always make the recipes on this site as written, and try NOT to make any changes until trying again if needed. This one is a KEEPER! Hubby already said add it to the Thanksgiving menu! Our cornbread hater of the family enjoyed it also!!! So did the neighbor I gave some too. I made it in a 8x8 pan, as that is what I had on hand. It was very full, cooked at 350 for an hour. It came out lightly crispy on top, moist in the middle, and oh,so AWESOME!

I really like this recipe.

I made just a few changes.   First I chopped up a single serrano pepper, and mixed it in - seeds and all to give a little color and kick.  I also split the batter between two pie shells.  Since it wasn't as thick I decreased the cooking time 5 minutes, and it came out great.  It's like a corny, light quiche.  :-)

text:
What I did. Doubled recipe. Used Marie calendars low fat honey butter cornbread mix. Did not use butter. Sprayed 9x13 glass pan with Pam.   Used one bag of frozen kennel born and one can of kernel corn (cheaper Safeway frozen corn).  Used two cans of cream corn.  This was good but next time trme try better  frozen corn. Added 4 beaten eggs  and 2 cups of light sour cream.  Did not sauté one sweet onion first and it was fine.  Added 3/4 of a pound crisped bacon. Next time use half of bacon inside and sprinkle top with remaininG  bacon and additional cheese on top for last 10 min. Did not sauté the onion first and it was fine. Made a lot but that was good because we had leftovers.

text:
As promised it was a "showstopper" according to the party guest who were observed licking the plate . I did take suggestions of adding onion and cheese. I uses a combo of Vermont white extra sharp cheddar with some fresh grated Parmesan. I also followed to suggestion of placing butter in bottom of the soufflé dish but I did not reduce butter in recipe. Just put about 3 T of melted butter in bottom. I made my own creamed corn from McKenzies frozen fried Iron Skillet corn with cracked pepper. I also used 2 T sugar and Krusteaz Honey Cornbread mix( gave it that grt honey flavor). I cooked for 1h 10 min as my oven cooks a bit slow until it was set in the middle and then browned it und
er broiler.I am making again as we speak per my husbands request for New Years day.This is so easy and a real winner !

text:
I have made this recipe every Thanksgiving for years, ever since it was printed in a local newspaper's holiday cookbook.  My family absolutely loves it!  The recipe I use has one additional ingredient, that being a 1/4 cup of sugar.  It really adds to the flavor, making it more like a corn pudding.  And, as one other reviewer noted, it takes at least 50 to 55 minutes to bake. Check at 50 minutes, but plan on it taking longer!

This is an amazing base for whatever your heart desires :)
I double everything in the orginal recipe then add whatever is in the pantry lol.
Usually two hand full's of fiesta cheese blend and a can of  genric Rotell. I have if you add more liquid (like not draining the corn, adding salsa, etc.) it takes at least an hour at 350' sometimes longer? Depends how moist you like yours? I've added pretty much everything to this casserole (turkey hot dogs, spam, sausage, hamburger etc.) it always gets eaten :) our favorite side dish with meats is butter beans with hammocks to flavor them and spinach with fried bacon and fresh cracked corn! 
But on that note this casserole can stand alone with a mixed salad anytime. So glad I found this AWESOME AWESOME RECIPE :)

Really the best corn casserole!! I add 1/2 cup of diced onion and 1/2 cup of diced red bell peppers. Since I like a bit of heat, I finely mince a jalapeño pepper and add to the mix. This had a great taste to it. I had it in the oven for 15 minutes before i realized I FORGOT THE SOUR CREAM! It tasted great without it, i wonder what the difference would be with the sour cream...at any rate it was a crowd pleaser. I am sure you could make this the night before and refridgerate it and bake it  for some time to warm it back up and maybe get a crisp top again but it really doesnt take any time at ALL to prep and put together and only 45 mins to cook. Also, once it has been in for its 45 mins don't be alarmed if it seems too soft or your fork doesn't come out smooth..remember the cream corn you put in :) its cooked! just let it sit and it will thicken and be yummy!

userID:
9157233
Display Name:
roc_mom
isPro:

16

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the same recipe I've made for years, and am asked to bring it to every gathering. BUT I add a pinch of salt, dash of pepper, 8 drops of Tobasco, and a Tablespoon or so of sugar, and sometimes add shredded cheddar to the top the last 10 minutes. It's great as written, but the additions give that something extra that stands out. I'll just say: one time there were 4 pans of corn casserole at a reunion, and people asked which one i made, and I always make a double batch, and there is never any left. The pickiest of eaters loved it, and literally Everytime I take it somewhere, people ask for the recipe. I discovered this in my early 20s, and my grandmother, great aunt, mom, mom-in-law, sister-in-law, aunts have all asked for the recipe, and despite it being so simple, having a signature dish that my elders loved so much, made me feel very proud. Even though they have the recipe, they still ask me to make it, Bc its 'my recipe' . And its so forgiving and so easy! This recipe will always have a special place in my heart.

I love this receipe.  I've made this for years, but I make one change.  I use two cans of CREAM corn and delete the kernel corn.  It's creamier.  Also, bake it in a 9x13 pan so it spreads out and cooks evenly, and NOT in a deep pan.  My in-laws hate it, but they are super super picky and don't eat much of anything.  My family loves it and I've had this at every Thanksgiving since I was little.  This recipe isn't for everyone, but is very good.

userID:
9225090
Display Name:
Beenon
isPro:

favoritesCount:
61

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this today in a 9x13 throw away tray and this is what I used: 2 boxes of Jiffy corn mix, 2 cans whole corn drained,  2 cans creamed corn, 1 1/2 cups of low fat sour cream, 1 stick I Can't Believe It's Not Butter (I use it for baking and it was the only butter I had), 3 packs of Splenda, 4 eggs.

It took about an hour to bake and to make it crispy on top, I reserved about 1/4 of the second box of corn mix to sprinkle on the top. The original recipe in a smaller pan (not doubled) called for 1 stick of melted butter. I don't understand how as using 1 stick for doubling the recipe was more than enough. If you are making this recipe from the original version I would suggest NOT using an entire stick of butter unless you are doubling it.

The final result was a sweet cornbread-like soufflé. It was not creamy, what I was hoping for, but needless to say it was still good and the entire tray was eaten. I brought it to a football party and it was definitely something different that I certainly will make again.

I've been following this recipe for the past two years, bringing it to family and church events - it works well every time!  I find that a single recipe does well in a glass pie dish, and a double recipe in a 9x13 pan.  I often grind a bit of fresh pepper on top before baking, also - wonderful!  (and I will admit that once I had things all set out, and the drained can of corn was by the sink and was inadvertently left out.  The dish just tasted a little more like a creamy cornbread, but it was still very good.)

Wanted to test run before trying on a crowd. Tried to follow the recipe as written except I did not have enough plain sour cream so used some chives flavor sour cream. Very easy, no fuss recipe that changes up a plain side dish.  Will double for large gathering.

text:
I have been making a version of this recipe for over 15 yrs. My original recipe didnt call for any eggs, but often I will add (in addition to my cans of corn) a quart of my home frozen sweet corn to expand the recipe and then I will add an egg to make it set up properly. To the person to was wondering if you can make it ahead of time? SURE...mix it all up, put it in the fridge and bake it the next day, it will be fine!

userID:
928997
Display Name:
Julie Pierce
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6057752.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this numerous times and everyone had always loved it.  It is so easy to throw together that we do not wait for family gatherings to make it anymore.  I noticed a few people mention in their reviews that it was a bit bland, but I think a recipe like this is meant to be seasoned to your personal taste.  You would not just dump a can of corn in a pan and serve it without at least adding butter, salt, pepper, etc.  So, I do not know why someone would make this and not season it.  I realize the recipe does not note this, but I just assumed that was a given.  I usually add salt, pepper, garlic powder, and onion powder when I make this.  No certain measurements, just a sprinkling until it looks about right.  Also, if you are looking for a little more interest, try using french onion chip dip in place of the sour cream.

text:
I read this recipe and read the reviews.  One reviewer had mentioned that she substituted cream cheese for the sour cream.  One other reviewer had mentioned chopped green chilies.  So, I doubled the recipe, added two cans of chopped green chilies.  I used cream cheese instead of sour cream.  I used four cups of frozen super sweet corn instead of canned corn.  I ran hot water over the frozen corn and let it drain.  I added one teaspoon of cayenne pepper.  I baked the 13x9 pan of corn pudding for one hour at 350 degrees.  I took it to Sunday dinner with the family and got RAVES!!!  It is now my favorite side dish recipe.

text:
My daughter gave me a version of this recipe several years ago and it's absolutely delicious.  She puts 1 cup of shredded Swiss cheese in with the other ingredients and after baking, puts 1/2 cup shredded Swiss cheese on top and it melts from the heat of the cooked cornbread.  She doesn't use creamed corn either, just a 8 oz. package of frozen whole kernel corn.  I never liked cornbread before I tasted this . . . it's not coarse and it's a sweeter version.  Yummy.

I have been making this same recipe for several years with one little extra ingredient: add 2 tablespoons of sugar. The sugar really boosts the flavor and makes this dish terrific. text:
I have also made this side dish for ages; an instant hit with NO left-overs!  HOWEVER: my recipe does not call for any eggs and the whole kernel corn is NOT drained.  I also use light sour cream and add some salt & pepper just to taste.  This is then baked at 350 degrees for an hour - be sure to spray your baking dish with Pam or other cooking spray!  Enjoy - this is definitely a trusty stand-by!!

I will try that version next time :).

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe even though I did change a few things. I used fat free sour cream cause that's all I had. The cornbread mix I had was only a 6.5 oz pack so I used smaller cans of corn accordingly. After mixing it all together, I thought it was a little runny so I added a teaspoon or two of corn starch. I also added a small can of green chillies,finely chopped onion and a Mexican bland of cheeses. Pinches of salt and pepper went into the mix and I topped with some of the cheese. It took about 55 minutes for it to get browned but the result was nothing short of amazing. I will now use this as my go-to corn pie recipe!

text:
This turned out to be just pretty good. Everyone raved over, however I felt it was a bit bland. I would give it 3 and 1/2 stars but that's not an option. What I liked about it is its creaminess and it's super easy to make. I did not use canned whole corn and instead used frozen corn (I steamed it before combining with all ingredients), I used light margarine, and reduced fat sour cream, simply because those are staples in our househole. I doubled the recipe and baked it in a 9x13 casserole dish for 110 minutes. Next time I make this, I would like to carmelize chopped shallots or an onion and incorporate that into the mix and add some fresh cracked pepper to taste and maybe a pinch or two of sugar.

text:
This was really good for today's Thanksgiving dinner. I made the recipe as indicated, but baked it in a 13x9 dish for an hour at 350 and found it to be plenty thick and with a great texture without "doubling" the recipe. I may have added a tad more sour cream than called for as I sometimes skip measuring and eye things, but it was moist without being mushy or underdone. Mine was not like a pudding and again in my opinion had wonderful texture... exactly what I was looking for in this dish; I say 5 stars for a wonderful recipe!

text:
Lives up to its awesome name and reputation, absolutely.  I took this to a funeral dinner today, and baked a small portion of it for myself last night.  Delicious.  I made a 9x13 pan, and baked for 90 min. I added sauteed chopped celery, green pepper, and red pepper. I had an envelope of "roasted corn soup" that I mixed in, dry, and I also added a 3/4 cup of divine garlic-gourney cheese that I bought for crackers.  Since it came in a 3 pack, I thought it would add a bit of the pizazz that others have said the flavor needs.  Oh, and I also added about a cup of grated low fat Mexican cheese. I will definitely be cooking this over many times.

(You may want to cook it for 1 hr to an hour + 15 min.  Just until the middle stops jiggling and when you can comb a toothpick clean.)  Very easy for a beginner and it was my first time trying it!!

I have fixed this awesome dish many times and just recently doubled it and served it as a side dish to our RV club at a monthly campout. I doubled it thinking that there would be some remaining and my hubby and I could have some the next day.  NO WAY!  They scraped the dish clean and demanded the recipe!   This recipes is THE BEST. I will make this dish over and over, and always double it for company so that there will always be enough to go around for seconds and thirds!

text:
This was sooo delicious!! I made some modifications, though. 

I halved the recipe but kept a whole can of creamed corn. This made it really runny and wet. If I didn't use a whole can, I'm sure it would have been more corn bread-like. 

I substituted plain non fat yogurt for sour cream. I substituted frozen corn instead of a can (no salt!). I added 1/2 a package of pepper jack cheese and 1/4 cup of jalapenos because my boyfriend loves it spicy. 

Even if I didn't make the substitutions, it would have been delicious!! I will DEFINITELY make this again.

text:
I enjoy another corn casserole from this site better, but this one is definitely easier and quicker.  This was very moist and I thought it could have cooked for another 5 minutes or so.  The taste was good, we like this on the sweeter side.  I used some other suggestions from reviewers - added 1/4 cup sugar, a teaspoon of vanilla and used 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 cream cheese.  This will be great to use when I'm pressed for time, thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family loves this recipe and have it at all of our family dinners. One exception to our recipe. We use only one stick of butter. Do not mix the butter into the recipe. Melt the butter in your baking pan. Mix the rest of the ingredients. Spread the mixture in the baking pan. The butter will come up along the sides. Spread it across the top and bake. This makes the edges nice and crunchy. Everyone fights over the end pieces.

text:
I made this recipe for the third time today and realized that I needed to give credit where credit is due.  I really like it because it is very, very easy to make.  It makes an excellent side dish.  I also made it once in place of corn bread muffins.  You obviously don't eat it like a muffin, but it has a similar taste and sometimes my cornbread turns out dry; but, this is a no brainer and has turned out perfect and the same each time.  I gave this five stars because it is easy and it is good; I really can't complain.  I don't know if I would describe it as awesome, because I can't help but wonder if something added might make it better.  I think that extra something might be bacon or green chilis or red pepper.  I just haven't got around to experimenting. This recipe reminds me of a good comfort food.  I think some extra ingredients could very well make it AWESOME!

text:
This dish is easy to make but did not turn out as a casserole. It's more like a pudding and is excellent for muffins. I used half the batter for a pudding and the other half for muffins. I thought the taste was bland (although the sour cream taste came through well): it was neither sweet nor savoury but some friends liked it that way. I will make this again if only because it is so easy to make but perhaps a little more cream or even milk next time to give it that casserole texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent.  I made it for Thanksgiving and got a lot of compliments.  As another reviewer mentioned, I could not find the 8.5 ounce-size of muffin mix.  I bought the 6.5 ounce size of Betty Crocker Corn muffin and bread mix.  I doubled this recipe and used 3 packages of the 6.5 ounce muffin mix.  I also added 1/4 cup of sugar to the doubled recipe.  It turned out great.  However, next time I double this, I may try to add just two of the 6.5 ounce size muffin mixes because I'd like to see if it would be a bit runnier, since the title makes it seem like it's a creamy casserole.  Mine turned out more like the other reviewers said, like a very moist cornbread.  It was delicious nevertheless!!  FIVE STARS!!!

text:
i highly recommend this recipe! i'm a vegitarian and made for my parents, who like comfort food, and we all LOVED it! i used a pie pan instead and it still worked perfectly. i also added about 1/4 cup chopped green onions, used fiesta corn, and added about 1/4 cup shredded mexican cheese. baked it for about 50 minutes, then sprinkled some cheese on the top and cooked about 8 minutes longer. YUMMY! inside was creamy, outside was crispy. definite five stars!

text:
Ever bought the "home mix" of that great corn cake you get at the local Mexican restaurant, and, when eating it, thought, "Yuck, this doesn't taste anything like what I'm getting at the restaurant?"

Well, this corn casserole does taste like what you get at the restaurant.  Yum!  I made it with the Double Crust Bean Pie (from this site), and everyone loved the meal!

The only change I made was to bake it in a 2.5 quart Corningware casserole, since I only had 8x8 and 9x13 bakeware.  I added ten minutes onto the baking time, and it came out perfectly!

text:
A nice change of pace from plain old corn.  My cans of corn were both 15 1/4 oz, and I had to use an 8x8 dish.  Because of this it had to stay in the oven a bit longer, but it was delicious when done.  My 3 year old (whose favorite food is candy) and husband (who is a picky eater) both asked for seconds.  It was a perfect compliment to our 'sweet hot and spicy' meatballs.  I'll definately make this again.
Review:

5

MOUTH WATERING DELICIOUS!  I'm not a corn person but this was fantastic!  I made it prior to thanksgiving to give it a trial run & ate myself silly.  Figured I'd hold off & make it for Christmas.

I did omit the whole kernel corn & doubled on the creme corn.  Awesome!  Now printed & put into my recipe box.  Hurry up Christmas dinner!!!!

None
text:
Excellent!  I doubled this for a lunch for some people from church and everyone loved it.  A keeper.
The only caveats I would say are: look closely at the labels of the products you buy.  In the store where I purchased the corn bread mix, only ONE was 8.5 oz.; almost all the rest were 6 or 6.5 oz.  Likewise, not all the cans of corn were exactly the size stated in the recipe.  If you must use products that have different measurements, be sure to adjust the recipe accordingly.

country:
None
text:
We loved this corn casserole!  It is so forgiving if you don't have exactly what it calls for.  I probably change it every time I make it.  It is such a great basic recipe.  I have added different chesses, onion, green chilies, red or green bell peppers, yogurt instead of sour cream etc.  It is always good.  I've noticed  that some people add sugar.  I think that is a regional thing.  I live in South Texas and I had never had sweet cornbread until my friend from Illinois made cornbread that was sweet.  It was more like a dessert.  So to each his own.  Thanks for a yummy favorite.

city:

country:
None
text:
I give it 5 stars made with my adjustments. I have had creamy corn casseroles before & they are all sweet.  I don't like sweet vegetables (like can creamed corn).  I used the niblets as the recipe calls for.  Instead of can cream corn, I found a chub of frozen Southern buttered fried corn (iron skillet fried corn).  Never had it before & didn't know how it would taste but if it is iron skillet Southern fried corn, I know it's now sweet.  I used it instead of the can cream corn and it turned out delicious. Omitting any amount of sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a work potluck and it ended up being super good, I wouldn’t call it a casserole though, it’s basically corn bread with a lot of corn hehehe. I doubled the recipe and put it into a 9x13 pan HOWEVER, if you follow the recipe, it ends up being a littttttttllle but too much so I ended up removing some from the pan so it wouldn’t overflow. I also added 1.5 TBS of sugar and a couple pinches of salt to taste. because I doubled it I ended up having to bake it for about 80 minutes at 350 degrees. The casserole is super moist so I kept thinking it wasn’t done but it was. I recommend adding the sugar and salt for a sweet and savory flavor.

I followed this recipe with the exception of using light sour cream and adding shredded cheddar to the top.  I also followed the tip of another reviewer that said to melt the butter in the pan and just pour the mixture on top. Next time I might cut down on the amount of butter.

text:
Been making this recipe for years with Jiffy corn muffin mix. (And actually have seen it as a recipe on the box) Have made it both with basically the other ingredients listed here and by using the MEXI-CORN. We personally prefer the MEXI-CORN version just because it adds that little ZIP...but...have added some green chillies when I couldn't find the MEXI-CORN. This is ALWAYS, ALWAYS, ALWAYS A MAJOR HIT and ALWAYS, ALWAYS, ALWAYS end up with an empty pan!!!! (And never fails to shock me when some say they have NEVER, EVER had this!!!) SOOO...LOL..just blows my mind when someone posts things like "...not one person even tried it, and ended up throwing the whole thing out." REALLY??? LOL...NOBODY EVEN "TRIED" IT, and you're just gonna THROW THE WHOLE THING OUT BECAUSE OF THAT??? REALLY??? (SMH) IDK. I understand that many people have different tastes. BUT...for there to be almost 2700 comments to this recipe and practically 95% of them find this INCREDIBLE...can only imagine that those 5% that thought something like this was just BLAND, YUCK and EWWWW have to be either MAJOR GOURMET RESTAURANT FANS or SOOO INCREDIBLY PICKY THAT I WOULD DREAD THE THOUGHT OF HAVING TO FEED YOU. All I can say is...I'm a 60 yr old Momma, Grandma that has lived both in the South and Midwest and everybody thinks I'm a genious in the kitchen. LOL..NO GENIOUS here!!!! Just an old lady that enjoys spending time in the kitchen, experimenting with my seasonings, ingredients, and creativity!!!

Recently made this for a holiday party. It was a hit! I had people who hated cornbread going back for seconds. Everybody agreed it was the 2nd best thing next to the Tri Tip that was cooked. I think that’s pretty good. Anyways I used reduced fat sour cream instead. As for the cornbread mix, I used Fleischmann’s Simply Homemade Mix. It was very easy to reheat as I cooked it the night prior. Will continue to make this yearly! Also wanna try it with hatch chili’s next time.

country:
None
text:
(4.5 Stars )

This was well received at Thanksgiving dinner as a side dish. I doubled the recipe for my guests and cooked for 55 minutes. I will do this dish again because it was tasty and easy to cook. Prepare a few hours before serving and let it set to firm and then keep warm. 

Suggestions (when you double recipe): Use 1/4 less of butter,  2 tablespoons of sugar, green onion,  2 cups  sharp cheddar or fresh parm cheese, and 1 red pepper (for coloring). 

Next time: Will add jalapenos for a kick and sausage

Edit: For the third time, I made for one serving. Used all the butter this time but added more cornbread mixing. Also instead of jalapenos, I included cooked spicy sausage. Family really liked it an said it reminded them more of a stuffing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The ingredient list of the "Spoon Bread Casserole" recipe by Jiffy calls for using the small size cans of corn (8.75 oz. whole kernel, 8.25 oz. cream style), not the larger cans (14-15 oz.). (The latter leave the casserole too wet, I find.) The Jiffy recipe also calls for an oven temperature of 375°, not 350°. Importantly, aim for the surface of the casserole to be quite golden brown. It shouldn't still be as blond as when it first goes into the oven.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely loved this recipe. It was quick and easy, and gently ushered me into the world of casserole-making. I'm new to the south and had no idea literally anything could be made into a casserole, so long as you had the rice and/or bread for it. I did use the general guidelines for this recipe, but I tweaked a few of the ingredients. I used sweet corn and creamed corn, and Mexican crema en lieu of sour cream. I also added 2 tbsp of sugar, just to sweeten it a touch. I baked it in a casserole pan for 35 minutes under 350, and it came out wonderfully.  I'll absolutely be making this again in the near future, and it'll become a holiday staple for sure.

text:
This recipe is perfect as is.  It truly is.  If you don't want to experiment and mess up a good thing, don't.  You'll end up with an amazing dish.  I personally use frozen corn instead of canned for a little more sweetness and crunch, add just a TBSP of white sugar, and sometimes melt some shredded cheddar on top, depending on whether we're in the mood for that or not, but it's certainly not necessary.  We also always double the recipe and cook in a 9x13 for maybe 10 minutes longer (do check though cause ovens vary) and it always turns out wonderful.  This is always my go to standard for corn pudding/casserole!  Thank you for the perfect recipe!  I'm making it for a potluck tomorrow in fact and I know I'll be bringing home an empty dish!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly as given. At 45 minutes, the crust didn't look brown enough. So I left it in for a few minutes longer as some others have suggested. I took it out of the oven at 50 minutes. It was tasty, with no raw or undercooked flavors. But it was definitely a bit too moist anyway. I will make it again but perhaps add some chopped onions for flavor, and bake it for an hour rather than 50 minutes. 

Of course it's called a "casserole" rather than a bread, so perhaps it's meant to be wet rather than more bread-like? Any ideas?

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6185639.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy to make and so well received every time. For me, absolutely no need to tinker with the recipe ... but everyone has their way and the alternatives are seemingly endless.  I doubled for Thanksgiving without making any  additions or subtractions,  using a 9 x 13 casserole dish and baking at 350 for an hour and 25 minutes. There was still some butter bubbling around the corners, so I lowered the oven to 200°  And let it sit for about another seven minutes or so, and ended up with beautifully browned edges.    The really nice thing about this recipe is that it's tasty at just about any temperature, so I didn't have to ask for oven space at my friends Thanksgiving dinner.    I kept the lid on the casserole, covered it with a kitchen towel, and it was still warm by the time we all sat down to eat.

My husband loves cornbread casserole and could eat it every week if he could.  This is a great standard recipe that comes out great every time.  The only thing I do is add about 1/8 cup sugar to sweeten it up.  Also this is never done in 45 min.  It takes at least an hour in the oven and I normally have to turn the oven up to 375 the last few minutes.  Great recipe!

text:
This was delicious.  I ate way too much of it!  But I have to say, it was only really good once I salted my own servings.  It is a little bland otherwise.  I recommend that you not use a smaller baking dish than recommended.  We only have 8" square pans, so I used a 9" round Corning Ware dish.  But the interior area is only 8" across, and that made the casserole take much longer to cook - more like 70 minutes for the center to be done.  Next time I'd use a much bigger dish so that it cooks faster.

text:
This looked really good and while collecting the ingredients, I could also envision a one dish meal. So I added ham bits and baby broccoli. Substituted cottage cheese for the sour cream. Yum! Update, this has morphed into a one dish casserole that we really love. Additionally, I have added a fresh tomato and 1/2 to 1 cup sharp cheddar cheese. I use Mrs. Dash Onion or Garlic seasoning about 2 or so tsps. I use Greek Yogurt or cottage cheese instead of sour cream. In other words this is a great base recipe that welcomes additions!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For crispy corn casserole cakes!!! 

- Omitted melted butter and eggs (too heavy) 

- Used softened butter to grease muffin tin. 

- Filled muffin tin 1/2 or 3/4 (up to you) 

- Baked at 350 for 45 minutes 

- Let cool for 10 minutes. 

- Sometimes, I add red pepper flakes or jalapeños.

I also make this in 8x8 and 9x11 pans. Always 70 minutes without melted butter or eggs. Prefer crispier edges.

Pic of corn cake resting on muffin tin in gallery!

text:
My parents and I loved this so much that we included it in our Thanksgiving dinner this year, taking the place of my moms Corn Soufflé that has been an addition to our Thanksgiving & Christmas dinners for generations.  
The second time I made it (for Thanksgiving) I added orange, red, and yellow peppers, which topped more greatness on this already great dish.  
Also, the only thing I do extra with or without peppers, is drizzle a little bit of  honey on top before it goes in the oven! Mmmm-mmm!
Review:

text:
I made this more than a dozen times so far. It's one of my family favorite side dishes. I used to make as is, except by using  a smaller package of corn bread mix. The brand I usually buy is little less than 7 ounces. But that shouldn't affect the recipe. 
Now a day I try to make it low fat , by using low fat sour cream, half butter and half olive oil. And even with these changes , this corn casserole / pudding  is still delicious.

userID:
16890472
Display Name:
Jeri DeCarlo Sessler
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2887555.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK.  Had this at Thanksgiving per the standard recipe and loved it but thought to mix it up a little.  I read all the comments on this recipe from people who had added things, so decided to jazz it up tonight.  This was a double recipe tonight.  I used herbs, seasonings and aromatics this time (garlic, green onion, salt/pepper, parsley, chives, thyme) and integrated with food processor into half the butter, then melted it on the stove before adding to the recipe.  Also added chopped green parts of green onions for color and flavor.  

I also added 3 tbl of honey, used a Krusteaz Cornbread mix (15 oz), and melted the other half of the butter in the bottom of the baking pan and did not incorporate it into the batter.  Used 8 oz sour cream and 8 oz cream cheese instead of double sour cream.  Fresh corn vs. canned sweet corn (8 ears), and then two cans of creamed corn.  I left the melted butter in the bottom of the pan, and then mixed the other ingredients together and poured on top of it.  I baked it 1 hour 25 minutes (the double recipe needed it, along with the added thickness).  Had to put the baking pan on top of a sheet pan in the oven as it threatened to overflow, lol.

OMG was it good!!!!  Half the recipe went between FOUR people!  It was nuts. My husband kept eating it and couldn't believe it was based on the same one we had the other night.  I will do this again and again!

text:
After reading reviews, I added half the water from the can of corn to further moisten the mixture. It took about 1 hour to bake and resulted in a moist, not overly sweet corn pudding casserole. I made this for Thanksgiving earlier in the day then just warmed it before the meal. The leftover casserole the next day tasted even better, and was tasty at room temperature too.

text:
I used to make a corn soufflé on Thanksgiving day but started making this recipe instead because it's so easy and delicious.  I double the recipe and bake  it directly in the crock of my small crockpot in the oven.  When it's done I place it inside the heating element part of the crockpot on low until it's time to serve.  This saves oven space.  The only change I make is to use sweet frozen corn (thawed out )in place of the can of regular corn.  I still used the can of creamed corn.

text:
Versatile! I didn't have room in the oven so I made it on top of the stove  with a few changes. 6 T butter , 2/3 C sour cream and 3 eggs. I used a heat range of just above medium and cooked it for 40 min. The only thing I will change next time (Everyone wants it  again for our Christmas brunch!) is that I will use a double boiler because it got a bit too brown on the bottom...though my brother said that added to the flavor.

I would definitely make it again because its easy and speedy preparation makes it an ideal side dish for a holiday meal.

text:
We love this for breakfast!   Make it exactly as written (no extra sugar, onions, peppers, cheese) and keep it in the oven until the top and bottom (use a glass baking dish) are golden brown.   Then while it sits on top of the stove, we fix sausages or bacon and serve squares of the baked corn with maple syrup!   It's absolutely fabulous and is now everybody's first choice - even more than waffles and pancakes!

I think it tasted even better the day after, which makes it a great make ahead item.  I tried it as is this first time, but I had to cook it for about 10 minutes longer than stated.  In the future, I will try adding diced green chiles and maybe even some shredded chicken.  I will even try for a low fat version in the future.

text:
I made this one evening when I was trying to just make something healthy for the kiddos to snack on for that day and also accompany a late brunch I had planned. I served it with a quiche and some garden salad. The kids asked me to please make it again.  I have SOOO much canned corn both creamed and whole kernel and I have bags and bags of corn bread mix from a friend who closed down her store and didn't see a big use for them. So for me not only is this delicious but so economical as well.  
The flavor of the dish was exceptional. I found it to be more like a souffle and had a very light, non overpowering on flavor. Almost French cruller ish.  I'm making a double batch in about 10 minutes. :)

text:
This is a bread not a casserole. I thought it would come out as a creamy corn side dish; but it was more like a corn-bread. I have added it to my bread receipes. I took suggestion of others and used 1 egg, 3 TBSP melted butter and 1/4 cup chopped onion. I baked it in a round casserole but would recommend a square dish so it can be cut as a bread in squares.

None
text:
Great, thank you! Mine was more fluffy than creamy, which I did like, but it does resemble corn bread with extra corn as some reviewers said. Here's the changes I made with suggestions by other reviewers:
- 1 egg, beaten
- 3 Tablespoons of butter, melted
- no sour cream
- 1 Tablespoon of sugar
- 1 Cup of shredded sharp cheddar cheese 
- Bake at 350 degrees for 1 hour. Let stand 20-30 minutes at room temperature.

text:
Awesome!  Go into to it knowing this: if you are expecting or wanting a creamier texture, make sure you don't use the 8.5 oz corn bread package....us the 6.5 oz.  I read the other reviews prior and left out about 2 ounces of my 8.5 oz box when making this....perfect!!  Still had the corn bread-ish texture but still creamy enough.  I would have been bummed if it came out like corn bread.  Other than that, followed the recipe to the ingredient.

country:

text:
I don't know why but I always end up changing recipes, but this had a great start base. I had a huge bag of left-over corn from a low-country boil in the freezer. (Earmarked for winter corn chowders, etc.) I add chopped fresh jalapenos, sauteed along with chopped garlic, sweet onions, sweet red pepper in 1/2 stick butter. Mix it all in bowl with one egg, a little milk, 1/2 cup (or less) 0% fat-FAGE Greek Yogurt, lots of pepper,1/2 box Jiffy cornmuffin mix (love that stuff! Prob cause it's SWEET!) some chopped fresh cilantro, and 1 1/2 cup of sharp cheeses...mix it all in a 9X13 glass buttered dish, add more cheeses on top (lightly)Bake an hour or so 350...and VOILA! BIG HIT! Making it again today by request. BTW...it  freezes well, even if it has previously frozen corn.  I always save uneaten cooked corn from cookouts...makes the best chowders, casseroles, etc. Has that wonderful Low Country boil flavor.
This is just as good with any corn, canned, frozen, etc. YUMMILY!

Display Name:
pam632

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/831297.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I visit a local BBQ joint and one of their sides is corn casserole. I love it so much that I had to find the recipe and make it myself.  I found this recipe via Pinterest. I liked it because it had no cheese in it like a lot of other recipes did.  I made a double batch for a family picnic last week.  I mistakenly omitted the eggs and halved the butter.  Oops!  I baked it for an hour because the other reviews said it took longer.  I let it cool after baking and refrigerated until serving.  i just heated it for about five minutes in the microwave before serving to remove the chill.   It was basically "room temperature".  It turned out delicious!  Everyone raved about it.  It was the only dish on the buffet that was empty!  This dish isn't overly powerful sweet or corn-tasting.  It's a consistency between corn bread and pudding.  I didn't salt it because the canned veggies have enough sodium.   I'm going to a friends BBQ picnic next month and will definitely be making this to take along!   It will also appear on my Thanksgiving table this year too!

Display Name:
Kestrel

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this was for my son's Cub Scout Blue and Gold Banquet. I'm making it for his high school graduation now. :)
In that time, I have made this DOZENS of times: every holiday, every pot luck, every month just cause. I love it. Love it. LOVE IT. I make mine with a tablespoon of sugar just to be a little sweet. I've always used my 13x9 and baked at 350 for 30 minutes. This makes a semi-soft (while hot) 3/4" slice. I think it is supposed to be served via scoop method, out of a deep dish container but this is easier and more readily measured to make sure all slices are equal. To reheat, I just pat my wet hands on top of the slice, wrap it in Saran wrap and microwave for 2 minutes. I call that "lunch." I told you I loved this stuff! We call it Corn Thing because it isn't really a pudding and it isn't really a bread. It's wonderful. Thanks for all the years of happy eating. I imagine I'll be making this at his wedding someday. :)
