country:
None
text:
This is similar to a corn dish available at El Torito Mexican restaurat - I did not find the texture dry at all, but I did make some changes to the recipe.

 - Used Frozen corn instead of canned corn
 - Used Jiffy corn bread mixture
 - 1 can of diced green chilis
 - Did not add sugar once I added the green chilis, but was considering it

My husband really like it and so did I.  I used an 8x8 pan and had no issues with it overflowing.

Super easy to make.  Great flavor and moist.  Even good the next day.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My original review disappeared, so I'll try this again. This was FANTASTIC! Easily my favorite dish of Thanksgiving this year! Scanning through MANY reviews, I made mine using only 1 egg, 1 can creamed corn and measured out frozen petite white corn (it's sweeter), added 3/4 tsp sugar, a pinch of salt, black pepper, onion powder and chives, sauteed 1/2 c vidalia onion along with a 4 oz. can green chilies. Mine fit perfectly in an 8x8" dish! I baked closer to an hour, reducing the heat to 325 the last 20 minutes. Perfectly golden color and slightly crispy edges, this will remain on the Turkey Day rotation for many years to come. I also foresee this side dish on the menu alot! This also makes great leftovers, even for breakfast, when warmed and drizzed with honey. Thank you for this "awesome" recipe!

hough747

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/338752.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful!  I was only serving three, so I split the recipe in 2 9x4.5" pyrex's.  I had a 25 lb turkey in the oven and wanted the bird and the casserole to come out at same time.  So 30 till bird was ready to come out, I turned turkey so the butt(or)neck was toward oven window-i was surprised, but it fit.  And next to it, both small casserole dishes fit, but i had to turn them at a slight diagonal angle.  Took the bird out at the right time (30 min into the casserole's cook time)  and had 15 min to let turkey rest & carve meat for the meal.  Casserole came out perfect 20 min later, roughly 50 total minutes of cook time.  I figurd the extra five would be required for temperature exchange after opening oven to remove bird.  It was perfectly moist in center, browned on outside and done enough to slice into thick pieces.  Wonderful compliment to the turkey and there was not a crumb left! (of one of the two 9x4.5"'s that is ;). I loved that it worked just popping it in with the bird instead of having to wait. Thanks for posting!

None
text:
I took over making this dish for holidays with my husband's family. One year, I was out of eggs and, of course, who has eggs on Thanksgiving. So, I substituted a 1/2 cup of Miracle Whip for each egg. It turned out fantastic! I only make it this way now.
Also, this is so easy that I rarely prepare ahead of time. On the occasion that I am forced to make this one ahead of time, I mix everything together and refrigerate. I leave the baking for the morning. This doesn't always work very well. It gets a bit crispier around the edges than I'd like, but not burned, so it is a little bit of a time saver.

This was a wonderful side dish for Thanksgiving. I did make some changes, but this is a wonderful basic recipe for you to play around with.   I did use half the amount of butter called for, and just about a half a cup of unsweetened applesauce, and it was still delicious.  I also added about a half of a cut up onion, salt and pepper to taste, and about 3 teaspoons of sugar.  There was NOTHING left in the pan after our meal, everyone LOVED it....even my picky kids!

text:
All 4 of my picky kids liked this recipe, so it gets 4 stats.  I thought it was okay.  Taste like mushy cornbread to me.  I added garlic powder and chopped onion, but it was still a little bland. I also used 1 3/4 cup frozen corn instead of the canned whole corn.  The addition of meat, maybe cheese or other seasoning would improve this recipe, and easily make it into a main dish.  Tested out for a Thanksgiving side, but I will not use it...too similar to stuffing or cornbread dressing.  Think I will go with "Slow Cooker Creamed Corn" for a side dish...try it out if you like cream cheese!

None
text:
This recipe was great and I was pleased to find a lighter version of our old recipe.  I didn't have the Jiffy mix so I substituted other ingredients to make my own, I used frozen corn so it had to cook a little over an hour.  Also I used 1/2 cup sour cream and 1/2 cup non-fat plain yogurt.  Then I used 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup apple sauce to further cut down the fat.  Despite all my changes, it turned out GREAT!!  Next time I might go all yogurt and all apple sauce.

text:
It wasn't too sweet, too dry, or too moist. What I did was used 2 cans sweet yellow corn (1 was creamed, the other was not). I also decided to add half of the corn juice that the yellow corn came. In my opinion, it was just the right amount. On a side note, the corn casserole tastes better on the days following the initial day. I would make this again, but make it a day in advance, so that it would be more flavorful the next day.

text:
Very moist, nice change from regular cornbread. I think we may use this as a starter receipe for a SW type breakfast cornbread since we didn't like the one I tried b/4 from this website. We only had 1/3c of sour cream & I think that is really enough. It does bother me that it calls for 1/2c butter. Since the dry pkg of cornbread mix I bought wasn't 8.5 oz, we added our reg cornmeal to bring it up to the 8.5 oz called for. We'll try adding sausage, can of green chillies, cheese & red pepper next time for a breakfast dish.

text:
Yum! I followed this recipe almost to the letter and received rave reviews at Christmas dinner.  Nearly everyone asked me for the recipe -- I'm glad the host had a copy machine so I didn't have to handwrite a dozen copies!
I doubled the recipe and baked it in a 9X13 dish for 70 minutes.  I made the mixture as called for with the exception of adding two tablespoons of sugar, a bunch of chopped green onions, and only using 15-ish ounces of cornbread mix since that's all that was in the box.
Great recipe and super, super easy!

This has become a staple at our holiday table, both at Thanksgiving and Christmas.  It is a nice change from the traditional green bean casserole, and it is very easy to throw together. text:
This is the simplest best tasting corn casserole or pudding that I have ever had.  Adults and children alike loved this recipe for thanksgiving and I definitely plan to make it again.  You don't have to wait for a special occassion to make this one.  This recipe is better than some others I have tried because you use 2 eggs.  Without the eggs, the recipe is too too wet and tastes not quite done even with extra cooking time.  This recipe is just perfect!!!  I highly recommend it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You just can't go wrong with this recipe! Here's why...
I actually doubled the recipe because I wanted it for a big crowd, but didn't have the second can of creamed corn that was needed, so I added an extra 1/2 cup of sour cream and 1 TBSP. of sugar instead. The mixture was very creamy and I was concerned about it being too moist---It was wonderful! After reading from others here that it needs a little more time in the oven, I baked it for 55 minutes. It was a lovely golden brown and mildly sweet. The inside was moist yet almost cake-like. Despite altering this recipe, it came out delicious- I don't think you could mess it up! It was a perfect accompaniament for the Bavarian Meatballs recipe from this site; It would go well with a multitude of dishes. It got a big thumbs up from the family- I will definitely be making this again!

text:
EXCELLENT.  I made this with some baked chicken and even my picky toddler liked it.  I only had to bake it for 40 minutes, but I have a really hot gas oven.  I personally think that cheese would ruin the sweetness of the dish.  But you could experiment.. with jalepenos or green chiles and cheese for a more savory flavor.. I did not add additional sugar, my cornbread mix was sweet enough.  I also used lowfat sour cream.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe for BBQ or Mexican food. Did not use any of the canned juice from whle kernel corn.  Only used 1/2 c. sour cream, but added 1/2c. buttermilk and 1/2 c. cream cheese (blend buttermilk, sour cream and cream cheese together). Also added 1/4 c. white sugar, 1/2tsp. salt, 1/2 tsp. pepper and green chiles.  Made earlier in the day and refrigerated. Pulled out of refrigerator about 45 minutes before baking to let it come to room temperature in 9x11 pan. Baked closer to 1 hour before it was golden brown on top. Was absolutely wonderful!  More like a sweet, spoon corn bread.

text:
This is a great dish.  I made it for Thanksgiving and my whole family loved it.  My sister even asked me to bring it a pot luck she hosted a few weeks later.  I made a few changes that other users recommended.  I used 1 cup of melted butter, added 1 tbs. of sugar, some salt, used corn muffun mix instead of corn bread mix, and I also sprinked cheese over it before and after baking (I don't think it matters what type of cheese).  I will definitely be making this over and over again.  Its a keeper in my recipe book :).

Made this one afternoon, just for something to do. It was nice because I had just about everything on hand. I did substitute Super Sweet White Corn (Frozen) for the whole kernal. Even my 5 year old is enjoying it. Thanks for the recipe

text:
This really is more like a souffle than a corn casserole. This was very heavy on the bread and also very sweet. It is a good recipe but was not what I expected. I had made homemade bread with this same meal and it was just too much bread overall. If I make this again it will be if I am not serving bread and also if I am making only a moderately sweet dessert. The family wanted to give it a 3 but the recipe did turn out so well, only our taste buds were at fault.
